newsitem.title: CONGO: S.Africa's Mandela heads for Zaire talks.
newsitem.headline: S.Africa's Mandela heads for Zaire talks.

text.p: South Africa's Nelson Mandela headed for Congo's port of Pointe Noire on Friday to escort Zaire's President Mobutu Sese Seko to talks at sea with rebel leader Laurent Kabila, South African officials said.

Mandela, who will chair the talks on the South African navy ship Outeniqua, was to arrive in Pointe Noire at around 0930 GMT with Mobutu expected there by 1000 GMT, the officials told reporters waiting to board the ship.
"The talks are due to finish today," one official said.
U.S. Navy helicopters overflew the airport at Pointe Noire on Friday morning as part of preparations. Mandela left South Africa for Pointe Noire earlier on Friday.

The South African officials said Mandela and Mobutu would board the Outeniqua in Pointe Noire and it would then go to Soyo on the Zaire-Angola border, where Kabila and Mandela's deputy Thabo Mbeki would join it by helicopter.
The ship would wait there in international waters.
Zairean officials in Kinshasa said Mobutu's entourage had left for the airport but there was no immediate word on Mobutu's movements. Pointe Noire is less than one hour's flying away.
Kabila, whose forces now control more than three quarters of Zaire, left on Friday morning for the Angolan capital Luanda, where he was to meet up with Mbeki.
